div.head: Editor's Pages
A CIRCUIT OF THE SOUTH IN THE SUMMER OF 1924
div.p: It was in September, 1920, that I came to Indiana University, but I did not teach in the summer session until 1924. Class-work ended that year on Friday, August 8, and Mrs. Lynch and I took a train for Louisville in the evening. For about a week, Indiana had been passing through a severe heat wave. This did not seem a very fitting time to begin a trip that would take us into the Lower South, but there was a certain advantage, the same being a strong probability that no warmer weather would be found in Dixie-land than we had been enduring in the Hoosier domain for a while. Indeed, for a few days, though the weather was hot, it was a bit less uncomfortable than it had been, and then a cool wave that included the entire South spread over the country from the West. Just as we got back to Ashland, Kentucky , a new torrid wave arrived in the Ohio Valley. Considering personal experience only, we could have asserted that the South was a cooler region than the North. However, we knew that, while we were favored by pleasant summer weather, fires were started in many furnaces back home and President Coolidge sat by a roaring fire at his new England summer home.1

After a night and a forenoon in Louisville , a city with individuaity and charm, we left for Bowling Green on an L. & N. train about noon on Saturday. The late afternoon and evening we spent with Dr. A. M. Stickles and family, and then ran on into Nashville . Professor Stickles has been at the head of the department of history in the Western Kentucky State Teachers College since 1908. Soon after his appointment, he became a wheelhorse in this instition and he
1 From Sunday. August 8, 1924, to Friday, August 8, temperatures were high in southern Indiana. Saturday (August 2). was mild, with the highest temperature 80" at Evansville : the next day it was 92" ; on Wednesday it was 98¢ ; on Friday and Saturday it was 82¢. Temperatures were lower at Nashville and Atlanta during this hot week. On Monday. August 11, the highest temperature at Evansville was 74¢. at Nashville 90¢, and at Atlanta 94¢. On Tuesday, August 12. the maximum was 82¢ at Nashville . It was on this Tuesday evening that the temperature dropped 80 suddenly while we were in Tuscaloosa . During the cooler period in the Lower South, from Tuesday to Saturday, with highest temperatures in the lower eighties, Indianapolis showed a maximum temperature of 76¢ (Thursday August 14) and a minimum of 61¢. On the same day, the Boston temperatures were 74¢ and 60¢ and, the next day, 70¢ and 60¢. On Thursday, August 22. the day after we got back to the Ohio River at Ashland. Kentucky , the highest temperature at Cincinnati was 94¢. For southern Indiana temperatures at Evansville are given, as Bloomington , during heat waves. is more apt to conform with the temperatures of the city on the Ohio than with Indianapolis .
has exerted a strong and wholesome influence in Western Kentucky . Many of his students have gone on to do graduate work, especially in mid-westedn Universities.

Reaching Nashville in the evening, we remained until late afternoon of the next day, which was Sunday. We made a quiet survey of the city, that, with its many cultured families and colleges, holds an enviable place among the urban centers of the Mississippi Valley. Our visit to the Hermitage, the wonderfully well-preserved home of Andrew Jackson, we reserved for a later trip, but Nashville we covered as thoroughly as was possible in the time at our disposal. The high opinion which we thus formed of the Athens of the South, the city on the great, southern bend of the Cumberland, in the midst of one of the richest farming regions between the Ohio and the Gulf, has been confirmed by various visits scattered through the ensuing fifteen years.

The night of August 10, we spent at Decatur, Alabama . This was before the extensive developments so apparent to everyone who has seen the Tennessee River area of northern Alabama in recent years had taken shape. In 1924, Decatur was a quiet town2 on the banks of the Tennessee with but a small and unassuming hotel, "The Lyons," where we stopped for the night. We strolled down to the river bank along a sleepy street. A soft breeze was blowing. One felt almost as if he had come to a place where all cares could be cast aside. In the negro quarter, many of the darkies had brought their chairs outside and were sitting on the sidewalk. One rather portly negro woman of advancing years had dozed off but still sat upon her straight-backed, splint-bottomed chair, though her head and shoulders hung down towards the earth with no support whatever.

On Monday morning, we rode to Birmingham, a modern city of the Lower South which had no existence until after the Civil War.3 Here we stopped at a well-appointed hotel, found up-to-date department stores and noted the excellent traffic regulations that were enforced. We visited Howard College and Birmingham Southern, and sought out other features of interest. On the whole, we were impressed with the
2 The ponulation of Decatur, Alabama , in 1920 was 4,752 : in 1930, it was 15,693. In spite of the depression. the city has grown in population, wealth and importance since 1930, because of the development of power along the Tennessee River from Decatur to Florence.
3 Birmingham was laid out in 1871. In 1880, it had a population of 3,086: in twnty years it had increased to 38,416: by 1920. the population had reached 178,806; in 1930. it had grown to 269,678.
idea that Birmingham was very much like a northern city,4 a view that has not been changed by later trips to and through this industrial center of the South with Besemer near by.

We arrived at Tuscaloosa late Tuesday afternoon. We at once discovered that we were in a southern city, a university town, and a place of much beauty and charm.5 It was about six-thirty while we were looking over the campus of the University of Alabama that the temperature dropped about fifteen degrees in as many minutes. This meant a fine evening and a good night's rest at the McLester Hotel. We stayed over until afternoon of the next day and again visited the University. The second half of the summer session was still on and we found a considerable number of students and several members of the faculty on the campus. It was at this time that we first met Dr. Albert B. Moore, head of the department of history and dean of the graduate school, one of the finest of the new generation of history teachers in the South. I later became much better acquainted with the University of Alabama , since I served as a visiting professor there in the summers of 1925 and 1927.

We next went to Montgomery where we spent two nights at the Exchange Hotel, from the veranda of which William L. Yancey spoke on the evening of February 17, 1861, preceding the inauguration of Jefferson Davis, which occurred the next day. It was in this address that the "Orator of Secession" said so eloquently—"The man and the hour have met"—though it seems he really had desired the hour to meet a different man. It was hard to disassociate the Montgomery of our time from the Montgomery which was the cradle of the Confederacy. I recall that, when my wife and I stood by the columns in front of the Statehouse, at the base of which is inscribed on the stone floor a statement relative to the inauguration of Jefferson Davis, I remarked with some feeling: "Right here a nation came mighty near being born."

Montgomery is a southern city6 on the Alabama River, a few miles below the junction of the Tallagoosa and Coosa.
4 The term " Pittsburgh of the South," has been applied to Birmingham. It is not for this reason that it is here thought of as a northern city in he South, hut because along with the absence of southern traditions and ante-bellum history. the city is so thoroughly a product of modern capitalism.
5
Tuscaloosa is about fifty-six miles from Birmingham, and is therefore quite a commercial and shopping center. Its chief glory, however, lies in the University and in the many fine homes, old and new, that it boasts.
6 The population of Montgomery in 1920 was 43,464 : in 1930, it had reached 66,079. It superseded Tuscelooss as the cagital of the state in 1847. As early a? 1860, the city had a population of 29,258, only a shade under the figure of 1900. forty years later.
It is in the center of what was the greatest slaveholding region of Alabama , a black belt in two senses—an area where slaves outnumbered free persons and a belt of black soil. This part of Alabama is still a cotton country, but it has been slowly changing and seems on the road to a diversified farming economy.

Leaving Montgomery on the morning of August 15, we took the train to a station called Chehaw, from which point, we engaged a touring car and explored the cotton lands and homes about the town of Tuskegee. We also visited the 42—Magazine of History—Editor's Notes (Continued) grounds and buildings of the famous Tuskegee Institute founded by Booker T. Washington. Then we went by an afternoon train from Chehaw to Atlanta . Here we stayed from Friday evening till Sunday morning, stopping at the Piedmont Hotel. On Saturday, we did some shopping, visited Emory University,7 and made a trip to Stone Mountain. This was while the sculptor, Gutzon Borglum was at work on the great project in memory of the Confederacy. He had already done considerable carving on the rock wall of the perpendicular side of the Mountain which has a rather gentle slope on the opposite side. It was not so long after our visit that, owing to a clash of opinion between the committee in charge of the project and the sculptor, the carving already done was effaced and the undertaking assigned to another artist.

We did not become much acquainted with Atlanta during our short stay. The city has a splendid location, the site being one where a city was bound to spring up with the coming of civilization. The strategic location has made the city one of the foremost business centers of the interior South, but it is also true that its site gave it such great military importance that it was of necessity fought for during the Civil War. Older than Birmingham, it has ante-bellum traditions and it played a part in the history of the Old South, but, it has, nevertheless, like its Alabama industrial rival, taken on many of the characteristics of a northern city.8

On Sunday forenoon, we made the trip to Chattanooga ,
7 An old friend, a classmate of student days at Indiana University, Prof. Emmett E. Giltner. was teaching at Emory University during the summer of 1924. For many years. he has been a member of the faculty of the New York Training School for Teachers and his home is at Yonkers.
8 I do not mean to criticise northern cities. I simply prefer that southern cities shall not be too northern. Uniformity of urban centers of the Unitedl States is not desirable, and I do not feel that to develop successfully the South must become a replica of the North.
passing through the mountainous country which Sherman traversed as his army slowly pushed the forces of Joseph E. Johnston toward Atlanta in 1864. We did not visit Chicka-mauga or Missionary Ridge on this trip, but we did spend a few hours at Chattanooga , using up most of our time at Lookout Mountain.9 The lower, northeastern end of this beautiful mountain ridge overlooks the city of Chattanooga and Moccasin Bend of the Tennessee River. The view is one that is worth going far to enjoy. Lookout Mountain is not a peak, but an eighty-mile ridge that stretches across the corner of Georgia and on into Alabama . For many miles, the crest of the ridge is in plain view from the highway that leads from Chattanooga towards Birmingham, a fact which renders a drive along this road one never to be forgotten.

After a short run, we spent the night at Athens, Tennessee , and then went on into Knoxville the next day. There, we visited the University and made a trip to Maryville11 by bus. East Tennessee has never ceased to fascinate us since our first trip through that wonderful country. In the summer of 1930, we lived for three months in Knoxville , occupying a professor's home at the highest point in the city, from which the view of the Great Smoky Mountains in the distance was unusually fine. This privilege, we enjoyed while I served as a visiting professor during both halves of the summer session of the University.

Leaving Knoxville , on our southern tour of 1924, we rode to Johnson City on August 20, and the next day traveled to Elkhorn City, Kentucky , by the Clinchfield line, and from there to Ashland by the C. & O. branch which serves a part of the eastern Kentucky coal field. This meant that we passed again along the route, which outsiders so seldom follow and over which we had traveled in December, 1922.11 This time we went in the opposite direction. As already mentioned, we met a new heat wave at the Ohio River, and it seemed rather strange that we should have experienced such pleasant
9 We used the inclined railway in going up Lookout Mountain and down again. This is one line of transportation over which I have never desired to travel again. Once should be enough for anyone. I would not mind to go straight up or down in an elevator. but the slight inclination from the perpendicular of the upper six hundred feet of this particular inclined railway made no appeal to me.
10 Maryville is about sixteen miles from Knoxville . It is the home of Maryville College and a great center for the manufacture of aluminum products. It is almost in the shadow of the Great Smokies, and tourists, who drive to Gatlinburg from Knoxville , usually pass through Maryville and the water-gap where the Little River cuts through Chilhowie Mountain, either when going or returning.
11 Our trip over this route in December, 1922, is described in my article, "A Southern Journey," Indiana Magazine of History (June, 1939). XXXV. 201–207.
days and nights in the South only to suffer from a high temperature on our return to the great river where the North begins. On August 22, we visited Huntington , West Virginia , and then took a Pullman to Cincinnati . This was the only night of fifteen that we spent on the train, our object being to punctuate our journey by short runs from place to place, and take these runs as far as possible in the daytime. Traveling from Cincinnati to Indianapolis , and then to Bloomington on a very hot day, we finished our summer-time, southern circuit on August 23.

The total cost of the trip was $277.31. The total railroad mileage was 1,760, and I paid out in fares (for two) the sum of $126.74. For taxi, street car, and bus fares (side trips), the outlay was $20.18. At hotels, the rate for double rooms with bath varied from $2.50 to $6.00, and we paid out for "lodgings" (fourteen nights, including Pullman berths for one night) a total of $62.00. The night of August 21, we spent with relatives in Ashland, Kentucky .12 The balance of our expenditure, amounting to $68.39, went for meals, entertainment and incidentals.13

At the time of this trip, cotton was not ready for picking and ginning, except in the vicinity of Montgomery and Tuskegee. Even in this area, these processes had just started, but we saw pickers at work and gins in operation. We picked some cotton with our own hands, as we have done many times since, and we studied the work of a modern cotton-gin. Many of these are out in the country. They are seldom painted, and are therefore dull and unattractive structures. They are, however, very efficient. They are a far cry from Whitney's simple machine, but are in reality the same in multiple form with other features added.

Our journey of 1924 was the last of its kind, that is, the last of our train trips made by easy stages for the purpose of becoming acquainted with the South. Since then, all of our sightseeing journeys in the South, and most of our trips
12 We stayed. at the home of Mr. and Mrs. William C. Myers. Mrs. Myers is a sister of the writer.
13 In all of our southern journeys. Mrs. Lynch and I have seldom fared badly in the. matter of selecting eating places. In our opinion, the South is equal to. if not ahead of, the North in respect to restaurant and cafeteria service for the general public.
for other purposes, have been made in our own automobile.14 The well-nigh universal motor-car makes touring easy and pleasant, but there is something to be said for the method of getting acquainted with the South which we used before we shifted from train to automobile.

div.head: The Collett Family
div.p: History records the name of this family as having been spelled Colet in France , where members of the family were merchants of Normandy. In 1066, the family went to England with William the Conquerer, where they were given large landed estates as loyal subjects. The family name was spelled Colet and Collet in the thirteenth and fourteenth centuries, but is now spelled Collett, both in England and America, by all the living descendants.

In 1221–1222, it is recorded in Gilbert's Documents of Anglo-Normans in Ireland and in the Calender of Justiciary Rolls of Ireland that William Colet and his brother Edward, sons of Walter Colet of England , established the "first of the Kings Inns or Courts" known as Collett's Inn, a school of law, in Dublin, Ireland . In 1362, this Law School was granted to the Prior and Friars of the Augustinian order of Dublin , and the Colets returned to England .

Sir Knight Henry Collett, wealthy merchant of London, England , in his will spelled his name both Colet and Collet. He was Lord Mayor of London in 1486 and again in 1495. The Arms, which were originally granted to him, appear on the Jacobean Monument in Chelsfield, Kent , to Peter Collet, an Alderman of London , who died in 1607. They are also to be seen on a Brass in the Church of Little Gidding, Huntingdonshire, and were borne by Thomas Collett, barrister, who died in 1675, son of John and Susanna Ferrar Collett, of London , all descendants of Humphrey Collett.

Seebohm states that John Colet, son of Sir Knight Henry Collet, was born in 1467 and died in 1519, graduated from Oxford in 1494, became Dean of St. Paul 's Cathedral, London , and, in 1512, founded and fully endowed St. Paul 's School for Boys, which is in operation today.1 Maurois writes of John Colet, of St. Paul 's, as Latinist, educator, and rich burgess—the most representative figure of his generation in England , a man of great learning.2

John Collett, who was born in 1578 and died in 1650, was a merchant and member of the Virginia Company of
1 Frederick Seebohm, The Oxford Reformers: John Colet, Erasmzcs and Thomas Moore ( London , 1912), 8, 9, 84. 128, 311.
2 Andre Maurois. Miracle of England
(An Account of Her Rise to Pre-eminence and Present Position), translated by Hamish Miles ( New York , 1937). 201–211.
London, England .3 In 1600, he married Susanna Ferrar, who was born in 1581, and died in 1657, the daughter of Nicholas and Mary Woodnoth Ferrar, of London . To them were born eight sons and eight daughters. In 1650, three of their sons came to Virginia : John, Fellow at Clare College, Cambridge University, married Ann Goldsmith Collett and had three sons; Richard, graduate of Middle Temple, College of Law, married Elizabeth—; James, graduate of Middle Temple, College of Law. James remained in Virginia , while John and family, and Richard and wife later relocated at Baltimore, Maryland . There, Richard followed his profession, and John became the first Clerk of the Court at Baltimore . The records of the court contain the following:
Since it has pleased God to take away John Collett, Clerk of this County, and the county business being neglected for want of a Clerk, by the advise of Jerome White we have, for the present, chosen one Thomas Salmon to act as Clerk. Done this November 29th, 1669, Thomas At-well, Godfrey Bayley, Jo. Vanluke, Commissioners. To the Honourable Governor. The author has a photostat of John Collett's will, recorded at
Annapolis, Maryland , and also a photostat of two letters written in 1650, found by Prof. A. L. Maycock in the Magdalene College manuscripts, Cambridge University. One of the letters is written to his sister Mary, and one to his uncle John Ferrar.

John Collett was born at Baltimore, Maryland , in 1760, died on January 22, 1834, and is buried at Terre Haute , Indiana.4 He married Elizabeth Stevenson at Baltimore in 1782. In 1786, they removed to Huntingdon, Pennsylvania , and, in 1797, to Chillicothe on the Scioto River, Northwest Territory. Here this Mr. Collett was elected Trustee and his eldest son Josephus was elected Sheriff for the years 1818–19. Elizabeth, John's wife, died at Chillicothe , where she was buried in 1803 in the year that Ohio was admitted to the Union as a state.

In 1812, when Columbus, Ohio , was founded, John Collett was one of the first fourteen men to buy lots in the new
3 John Collett (1578–1650) was a descendant of John Colet (1467–1519). This has been fully established and the writer of this article has adequate proof.
4 John Collett (1760–1834) was a descendant of John Collett (1578–1650). This has also been fully proved. The author has omitted some of the early history of the family to save space. Mr. Henry Collett of 64 Cornhill, London , EC3. England , has full data on the Collett family in thk early period. and there is a history of the Collett family in the British Museum, the first volume of whlch includes matter pertaining to the family prior to 1760.
town. He bought lot number 262 on High Street, a half block from the present State House. There he built the first brick building in Columbus . His daughter Mary's marriage, in 1813, to Josephus Dillow is recorded as the second marriage performed in Columbus . On September 8, 1818, John Collett sold his realty holdings in Columbus, Ohio , to Robert Russell and removed to Terre Haute , Indiana, where he and his sons, Josephus and Stephen, had been appointed government land surveyors for Indiana. The father., John Collett, surveyed Townships 12, 13, 14, 15, and 16, ranges 4 and 5 West; Josephus surveyed Townships 17, 18, 19, and 20, ranges 2 and 3 West; Stephen surveyed Townships 12, 13 14, 15, and 16, ranges 1 East, and 1 West.

Stephen S. Collett was born on December 26, 1791, at Huntingdon, Pennsylvania . He died on December 25, 1843, at the Browning Hotel, Indianapolis , Indiana, while serving in the Indiana Legislature, and was buried in Terre Haute , Indiana. He was married on November 8, 1821, to Sarah Groenendyke of Terre Haute . Sarah was born on July 6, 1804. She was a daughter of John and Lucretia de Rapalje Groenendyke. She died on March 2, 1852, and was buried in Terre Haute . Three sons and six daughters were born to Stephen and Lucretia Collett. Mr. Collett, having retired from Government service, became a merchant in Terre Haute , 1822–1826, a partner of William C. Linton. Later, Chauncy Rose joined the firm, which then became known as Rose, Linton and Collett. In 1824, Mr. Collett established the townsite of Newport , and in 1826, the townsite of Eugene, both in Vermillion County , Indiana. In 1827, he removed his family to Eugene where he and his brother Josephus entered the mercantile business. They successfully operated a store for a number of years. Stephen S. Collett was a Representative from Vermillion County , 1833–34, in the state Legislature and State Senator from Vermillion , Parke, and Warren Counties in 1835–36. He was also Senator from Vermillion and Parke counties in 1843–44.

div.head: Queries and Answers
div.p: Query 87: HENSON FAMILY

William Henson died at Trinity Springs, Martin County, Indiana. His parents came from Kentucky to Ohio , and he came from Ohio to Indiana. We do not have dates, but the 1830 census of Martin County, Indiana, shows a William Henson living there in that year. Of his children, one daughter married Thomas Gore of Burns City, Martin County; another daughter, Sarah Jane Henson, born March 23, 1822, married George Fox, who was born in 1828 in Columbiana County, Ohio , and died at Harrisonville, Martin County, Indiana. Any information relative to this family will be appreciated.—R.E.A.
Query 88: CARR FAMILY

Jonathan J. Carr, husband of Martha Carr, died in Morgan County , Indiana, in 1845. He served in the War of 1812 from Clark County , Indiana, and lived for a time in Washington County . A deed to his son John, dated January 4, 1830, shows that he was living in Morgan County at that time. His son John, was born in 1804, in Kentucky , according to the census of 1860. He maried in Washington County , Indiana, on July 14, 1829, Sarah Comer Wilson, a widow with two small children. They are buried in Coles County, Illinois . Letters indicate that the children of Jonathan and Martha Carr were: John, William, Jackson, Austin, Jonathan J., Andrew (?), and perhaps a daughter Sally Ann. The parentage of Jonathan J. Carr is desired, with maiden name of wife, dates, and any information concerning descendants.—G.B.W.
Query 89: CRAIG FAMILY

William Craig was born on June 14, 1810; and died on May 30, 1874, in Harrison County , Indiana. He married Elizabeth Meyers. She was born on March 30, 1808 and died on May 9, 1894. They lived near New Amsterdam, Harrison County . According to family records, their children were: Sarah (married Abraham Breden) ; Christine C. (married John Bandenburg) ; Nancy (unmarried) ; Green Gaines (married Mary Kinder) ; Robert Marion (married Sarah Breden) ; Alva, served in Civil War. A William Craig is thought to have been the grandson of James and
Mary (Laird) Craig. James Craig served in the Revolutionary War, was born in Ireland , and died in Augusta County, Virginia , in 1791. The family was originally from Scotland . The parentage of William Craig, date of marriage, proof of connection with James Craig, the Revolutionary soldier, and any information in regard to the family in Harrison County , Indiana, is wanted.—B.C.G.
Query 90: MCCOY FAMILY

John McCoy and Jane Collins were married on October 13, 1803, probably in Kentucky . Their children, born in Clark County , Indiana, were: Lydia, born 1804; Lewis, born 1806; Spencer Collins, born April 17, 1807; Isaac, born 1809; Thirza, born 1810; Mahala, born 1812; Eliza, born 1813; William, born 1814; George Rice, born 1817; John C., born 1819. Further information is wanted about this family, especially the name of the parents of Jane Collins.—E. McH.
Query 91: COFFIN FAMILY

Zacharias and Phebe Coffin of North Carolina had the following children: Abigail, Elisha, Cyrene, Hervey, Alfred, John, Maria (Mariah), Nathan Dicks, Phebe. Mariah, born December 17, 1815, married (1) a Mr. David, (2) a Mr. Cathon, (3) a Mr. Haskett. I have complete birth, death, and partial marriage records of this family from 1782 to 1886. Would like to exchange data relative to this family and correspond with descendants of the following pioneer families of Kentucky : John Collins (wife, Jemina), 1787, in Fayette or Jessamine County; George Cleveland (wife, Esther Sherwood), of same county; William Morris (wife, Sally), and Henry Walker (wife, Elander), both of Wood-ford County 1797–1799.—C.C.C.

Answer to Query 29 (June, 1937, p. 250, L.P.P.) : Price E. Prewitt was born in Kentucky about 1808, the son of Joseph and Patsy (Elliot) Prewitt, or Pruitt. He was married to Elizabeth Stewart in Shelby County , Kentucky , on October 11, 1831, and died in March 1877 (or 1878) in Owen County , Indiana. His wife died in 1841 or 1851 in Greene County , Indiana. Their son, De Wilton S. Prewitt, was born on December 27, 1839, in Greene County . He served throughout the Civil War (enlisted July 6, 1862, in Company F, Sixth Indiana Volunteer Cavalry. His brother,
Joseph, also served in the Union Army, but another brother, William, was in the Confederate Army. De Wilton S. Pruitt married Elizabeth Light on August 5, 1866, in Owen County , Indiana. They moved to Adair County, Iowa , in 1876. He died at Fontanelle, Iowa , his will being recorded in Adair County, Book 6, p. 130. Their children were William Ros-coe, Leonard Wilson, Joseph Allen, George Ashley, and Albert Wesley. William Roscoe Pruitt was born near Freedom, Owen County , Indiana, on July 11, 1868, and married Juniata Ringler at Marengo, Iowa , on April 12, 1898. They have one son, Lester Lee, born August 24, 1899; Leonard Wilson Pruitt was born in Owen County on April 26, 1870. He was first married to Mary Flaharty, in Adair County, Iowa , on July 25, 1894, and they had three children. After the death of his first wife, he maried Mrs. Anna Nielson Benson of Kansas City, Missouri , on July 4, 1924. Joseph Allen Pruitt was born on September 14, 1871, in Owen County , Indiana, and died on April 2, 1931, in Adair County, Iowa . He married Lillie Martin on November 20, 1901, and they have three children. George Ashley Pruitt was born on May 21, 1878, in Adair County, Iowa , and died on April 19, 1933, in Iowa . He married Nettie I. Kenner on December 20, 1899. They have four children: Albert Wesley Pruitt (born on August 3, 1880, in Adair County, Iowa ; died in 1924 at Los Angeles, California ; married (1) Ollie B. Green; one son; married (2) Esther May Moore) ; L. D. Prewitt, Forest City, Iowa .

Answer to Query 52 (March, 1938, p. 137, M.E.M.) : Uriah Glover (1740–1830) married Elizabeth Robinson (1744–1822). The family record of John B. Glover, greatgrandson of Uriah Glover, states:
My great grandfather was born on Long Island in 1740, where he probably lived until he was a full grown man, when he crossed over into New Jersey and located near Elizabeth. This was some years before the Revolutionary War. Here my grandfather, Uriah Glover, Jr., was born in 1773. While he was a young man his father moved to Uniontown, Penn., where the entire family remained until 1797, when they 'sold out,' and started for Louisville , Ky. They came down the Ohio River on a flatboat. The landing was made just above the falls, where the city now stands. They 'pushed out' into the country and settled in Shelby County , Ky. Just before leaving Penn. my grandfather married Priscolla Gaddis, daughter of Col. Thomas Gaddis, who was a gallant soldier in the war of the Revolution.

Sarah (1807–1847) daughter of Uriah Glover, Jr., and Priscilla Gaddis, married (1) Fielding D. McGrew and had one child, Fielding Rice McGrew (1828–1849), who died unmarried; (2) John Daniel Shyrer, and had five children, the youngest, Mary Sophronia married James Ferrier, my father. Records of the Glover family have been compiled, but the Revolutionary service of Uriah Glover, Sr., has not been proved.—Miss Mary Ferrier, 228 West Front Street, Jeffer-sonville, Indiana.

div.head: Abstracts of Early Wills and Executors' Records1
div.p: Miller, David. Administrators, widow Elizabeth Miller and David Fanisin, appointed May 5, 1814. Bond, $500. Securities: David Irwin, John Ferguson ( Clark County Will Record A, 1801–17, 96). Appraisement of personal property (Vol. B, 1817–33, 144–146).
Bowman, John. Administrator, Leonard Bowman, appointed May 27, 1814. Bond, $400. Securities: Andrew Gelwick, John Ferguson (ibid., Vol. A, 97).
Hartley, Jonathan. Administrator, William Hartley, appointed June 4, 1814. Bond, $100. Securities: Henry Huckleberry, William N. Griffith (ibid., 98).
McCannon, James. Administrator, James Drummond, appointed September 3, 1814. Bond, $300. Securities: William Ferguson, John Work, Jr. (ibid., 98–99).
Marsh, Elias. Administrators, Samuel and Robert Marsh, appointed October 11, 1814. Bond, $2000. Securities: James Anderson, Elkin Marsh (ibid., 99).

Sage, James. Administrator, Abraham Epler, appointed October 24, 1814. Bond, $1200. Securities: Charles Beggs, John Ferguson (ibid., 100–1). Appraisement of personal property (Vol. B, 1817–33, 131–33).
Sumner, William B. Administrator, widow Ann Sumner, appointed November 1, 1814. Bond, $1200. Securities: Alexander Buckner, James Scott (ibid., Vol. A, 101).

Huffman, Peter. Will dated August 30, 1810; probated July 1, 1813. Heirs: wife, Catherine; children: Benjamin, Rachel (Mrs. Henry Collins), Isaac, John, Mary, Winifred, Ann, Catherine, Rebecca. Executors: Catherine Huffman, son, Isaac Huffman. Witnesses: Moses Cook, John R. Clark, Nancy Cook (ibid., 101–2).

Dowden, Thomas. Will dated July 13, 1812; probated October 12, 1812. Heirs: wife, Nancy Dowden; son, Zephaniah. Executor: Nancy Dowden. Witnesses: James Ferguson, William Dowden, Georme Summers (ibid., 103). Inventory of estate made October 15, 1812 (Vol. B, 1817–33, 147–48).

Parks, Andrew. Will dated July 21, 1812; probated November 23, 1812. Heirs: wife, Margaret Parks; children, John, Sarah. Executor: Margaret Parks. Witnesses: John and Sarah Parks, John Newland, John W. Coffey, John Sutton (ibid., Vol. A, 104–5).

Nugent, Willoughbu. Will dated January 13, 1812; probated October 14, 1812. Heirs: wife (name not given); children: Elender Adkins, John Ross, Ignatius, Benedick, Levi Augustus, David; grandchildren, William May, Polly Nugent. Executors: James McCoy, Levi Augustus Nugent. Witnesses: David Croce, John Montgomery (ibid., 108–9).

Huckleberry, George. Will dated September 29, 1806; probated

January 9, 1813. Heirs :wife, Barbara; children: Henry, Jacob, John, Martin, Susanna, George, David, Abraham, Elizabeth. Witnesses: John H. Boldwin, Peter McDonald, Joseph Shaw (ibid., 110–11).

Stewart, James. Will dated April 4, 1810; probated March 22, 1813. Heirs: wife (name not given); children: Stephen, Isaac, Merchant, David, Elizabeth, Rebecca; Sarah Fleehart (relationship not indicated). Witnesses: William Goodwin, William Akin, Amos H. Goodwin (ibid., 112–13).

Stutsman (or Stootsman), Jacob. Will dated August 7, 1810; probated December 28, 1813. Heirs: children, Mary, Jacob, David, Samuel, Daniel; Philip Warman and Thomas Hutcheson (possibly sons-in-law). Executor: son, Daniel. Witnesses: Christian Parkey, Graham Anderson (ibid., 113–14).
Pearcy, Blake. Administrator, Thomas Pile, Appointed January 17, 1815. Bond, $400. Securities: Thomas Weathers, William Ferguson (ibid., 120).
Fait, George. Administrator, Andrew Fait, appointed March 27, 1815. Bond, $200. Securities: John Lemon, Henry L. Minor (ibid., 120–21).
Smith, Mary. Administrator, Peter Smith, appointed May 23, 1815. Bond, $2000. Securities: Alexander Buckner, Henry L. Minor. Inventory of estate made June 1815 (ibid., 121, 141).
Herrod, James. Administrator, Sarah Herrod (mother), appointed July 19, 1815. Bond, $250. Securities: George Newland, William P. Meredith. (ibid., 122).
Owens, Hervey. Administrator, John Owens, appointed July 22, 1815. Bond, $700. Securities: William P. Meredith, James McCampbell (ibid., 122–23).
Seveney, Thmas. Administrator, Mordecai Seveney, appointed August 1, 1815. Bond, $300. Securities: James McCampbell, David Vance (ibid., 123).

Hawn, Conrad. Administrator, David Spanger, appointed August 10, 1815. Bond, $1000. Securities: John Douthitt, James McCampbell. Appraisement of personal property and bill of sale (ibid., 124, 144–49).

Robison, William. Administrator, widow Martha Robison, appointed October 2, 1815. Bond, $400. Securities: James Seaton (?), Joseph Roberts (ibid., 125). Appraisement of personal property made October 4 and 5, 1815 (Vol. B, 135–36).

Bowmun, Joseph. Will (no date). Administrator, William Bowman, appointed February 26, 1816. Bond, $12,000. Securities: John Douthitt, John Weathers. Heirs: brothers and sisters, not named except for sister, Thompson; James Fisler; Sally Steed. Negro woman named Delphey to serve his sister for six years and then be liberated (ibid., Vol. A, 126, 133–35).

Reed, William. Will and codocil dated March 28, 1814; probated May 4, 1814. Heirs: wife, Sarah Reed; children, names not given except for eldest son, Joseph. Executors: Sarah Reed, Joel Coombs. Witnesses: William Herrod, James Fordyce, Robert Weir (ibid., 126–28).

Brown , John. Will dated February 28, 1814; probated June 8, 1814.
Heirs: wife, Polly Brown ; children, names not given except for son, Samuel. Executors: Isaac Lamb, Polly Brown . Witnesses: William Temple, Reuben Rucker (ibid., 128–29). Appraisement of personal property made June 13, 1814 (Vol. B, 159–61).

Roby, Leonard. Will dated June 8, 1815; probated August 2, 1815. Heirs: wife, Lucy Roby; children, names not given except for daughter Betsy and son Henry. Executors: Henry Roby, John Miller. Witnesses: Henry Bottorff, Abraham Epler, John Kelley (ibid., Vol. A, 130–31). Appraisement of personal property and bill of sale (ibid., 142–44, Vol. B, 101–4).
Pile, Richard. Administrator, widow Rebecca Pile, appointed March 26, 1816. Bond, $800. Securities: James Lemon, Samuel Merriwether (ibid., Vol. A, 131–32).

McCann, Thomas. Administrator, Jonathan Lewis, appointed April 10, 1816. Bond, $1000. Securities: Richard Aston, William P. Meredith (ibid., 132, 135). James Lemon appointed administrator on August 18, 1819 (Vol. B, 93).
Kelley, Thomas Ferguson. Administrator, John Kelley, appointed April 19, 1816. Bond, $100. Securities: James Lemon, Samuel Prather (ibid., Vol. A, 133).

Blowman, Mary. Will dated June 6, 1814; probated March 26, 1816. Heirs: sister, Elizabeth Thompson, and on her death to her children, Susan and Samuel. Executor: Samuel Gwathmey. Witnesses: Roderick Griffith, Basel Prather (ibid., 136–37).

Provine, Mary. Will dated August 26, 1815; probated September 4, 1815, in Jefferson County , Indiana. Heirs: children, William, Alexander, Ann Henderson, Polly McClintick, Rebekah McClintick; three grandchildren of deceased daughter, Sarah Harris. Saddle to negro woman Judy with request that no steps be taken to bring Judy and her children into bondage. Executors: son, William, John Telford. Witnesses: William Dunn, John Maxwell. Bill of sale (ibid., 137–38, 168).

Provine, William. Will dated October 11, 1816 [1815]; probated November 6, 1815. Heirs: wife, Polly Provine, and children, names not given. Executor: Polly Provine. Witnesses: William Gulick, Joseph Reese, John Telford. Appraisement and personal property and bill of sale, December 21 and 23, 1815 (ibid., 139–40, 169–75).
